ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Concepts in multivariable calculus and problem solving skills.
Multivariable calculus knowledge! double and triple integrals, line integrals, stuff in 3D, etc. It was really cool stuff!
I learned how to conceptualizar functions in 3 dimensions.
I learned about multivariable calculus
Math
problem solving

Great class especially if youre taking Physics concurrentlyhonestly its incredibly useful for developing an actual understanding of Calculus and it makes approaching concepts in Physics so much easier
I gained knowledge in multi variable calculus, and of 3d geometry. I gained skills in computing different types of integrals over 3D surfaces.

Understanding of multivariable and vector calculus. Including partial derivatives, extremum, 3-D space, double and triple integrals, line and surface integrals, integration theorems (Green's, Stokes', Divergence).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The lectures are very good and the psets are well designed for the exam content. Class time could have been structured better.

Strengths: it's well-organized. the videos were simply amazing. literally all the information you could need was found in the videos. The teaching in the videos was unambiguous, in-depth, and easily understandable all at once. literally fantastic.

weaknesses: the time in class didn't always feel the most useful, mostly because I feel like I prefer to learn in the classroom than by watching videos on my own time.
I think a cheat sheet on our tests wouldve been useful because there was a lot of information to memorize.
I think classes could be made more engaging and interactive.
Nice assignment schedule
videos before class helped a lot, well organized

The course material is excellent, but the way it was taught was pretty bad in my opinion. I wish that instead of watching explanatory videos in advance of the class we couldve had the class time for explanation of concepts and videos for practice problems. Instead, we were made to watch videos and class was a weird hybrid of review + practice which didnt help at all when approaching the PSets. Honestly the Ximera saved me for this class.

One strength of the course is that there are many resources available to you to help you comprehend the course material. The online content, lecture, office hours, peer tutors, and many other forms of help are all available to students to help them do well in the course.

Having problem sets due the same week as an exam was a huge weakness. Although the material of these problem sets was relevant to the exams and therefore helpful to study, the timing could have been better. I think it's an issue of course organization.

A huge strength of the class are the peer tutors. Emily in particular was incredible at filling in the gaps in my learning and helping me fully comprehend concepts.

Strengths: this course provides a good overview of the concepts, which are essential for more complex courses in math and physics. I enjoyed having a smaller class size, which made it easier to ask questions and interact with my professor. Personally knowing my professor from classes made me feel much more comfortable attending office hours and asking for help. Although the problem sets are generally more complex than examples reviewed from class, they follow directly from what was done, which I enjoyed. I liked the chance to expand on what I learned from class in problem sets and appreciated that they were also easier than the exams, which were fairly straightforward (so that if one understood the problem sets well, they could succeed on exams). Weaknesses: although this course does teach all the necessary concepts, it is overall poorly designed. In the case of my section, I watched lecture videos or read the textbook prior to class, only to relearn the concepts in class and/or review many redundant examples. Overall, I had to spend many hours inside and outside of class learning (and relearning) topics that were not particularly challenging. The class is overall effective in teaching but could be improved by removing some of the redundancies--lessening the work that must be done outside of the class and including more teaching (and less examples) inside of the classroom. The workload of the problem sets were fine, and I did enjoy completing them. It was just the pre-class work that was more tedious and unnecessary.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, unless it is required for the major as lower level calculus courses are probably easier.
Yes!!! It's very cool and a fun challenge. The organization is great, you always know what to expect, the practice tests are really good test prep.
If you want to learn calculus and do not mind to teach yourself most of the course content from the textbook.
If they had to take it, yes.
No, unless you have to take it for your major. A good alternative seems to be ENAS 151.
Yes
yes
Yes, if you are interested in going into STEM

I would recommend this course to another student. The professors all clearly help you to understand the course content, and as I mentioned above, students have access to many other resources to help them do well in the course.
I would recommend this class to the interested students who is also prepared to put in some work to learn the material.
